conclusion: Determine the radius d of the circular light-blocking plate that ensures no light exits from the inner surface of the hemispherical shell.
The shell has an inner radius R and an outer radius R' = sqrt(2)R. The refractive index of the glass is n = sqrt(2).
The shell is hemispherical with the central axis OO'. Light is incident parallel to the axis OO' on the outer surface of the hemisphere.
For total internal reflection at the inner surface, the angle of incidence inside the glass must be greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle theta_c is given by sin(theta_c) = 1/n = 1/sqrt(2), therefore, theta_c = 45 degrees.
Consider a light ray incident at the outer surface at a distance x from the axis OO'. The light refracts at the outer surface and travels through the glass.
To ensure total internal reflection at the inner surface, the angle of incidence at the inner surface must be greater than 45 degrees.
The angle of incidence at the outer surface is 0 degrees (since the light is parallel to the axis). The light enters the glass without deviation because it is normal to the surface.
The maximum angle of incidence at the inner surface occurs for the light ray that is tangent to the inner surface. This ray will be at the maximum distance from the axis, which is R.
The light ray that is tangent to the inner surface will exit the outer surface at the maximum distance x = R' sin(theta_c).
Since theta_c = 45 degrees, we have x = R' sin(45 degrees) = sqrt(2)R * 1/sqrt(2) = R.
The radius d of the light-blocking plate must be R to block all light that could potentially exit the inner surface.
